PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: Egyptian Preference Bonds.
div.p: The Bank of England are prepared to receive the coupons due the 15th instant on 'Egyptian Preference Bonds. The necessary lists can be procured on application at the dividend pay office.

div.head: The Mahmal Ceremony.
div.p: The ceremony of the return of the Mabmal| was held yesterday at Cairo. The Khedive was present accompanied by Moustapha Pasha Fahmy and Boutros Pasha Ghali. As his Highness drove up in state the band of the Egyptian Cavalry played the Khedivial authern and a salute was fired.

div.head: For the Red Sea Lighthouses.
div.p: We have received a box full of English novels of the Tauchnitz series from Mr Brothers, manager of the Bank of Egypt at Assouan, for the English lightkeepers in the Red Sea in the service of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration. We will consign the books to the Administration,

div.head: Coal Imports,
div.p: Between January 1 and April, 11,372,622 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 201,660 tons 'were Welsh, 73,205 Newcastle, 58,799 Yorkshire, 17,130 Scotch, and 21,828 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 350,818 tons.

div.head: Wheat in the Sudan.
div.p: While the area under cotton decreased last year compared to 1905, the area under wheat increased from 22,075 to 25,413 feddans, an increase of 3,338 feddans. The immediate future of the Sudan agriculture is believed to be more in the direction of the cultivation of wheat and other cereals than in that of cultivating cotton.

div.head: Tour Eiffel.
div.p: The programme of the Tour Eiffel remains so often unchanged that it was with more than unusual pleasąre we noted some new and excellent numbers on Saturday evening, that of Mr. Brosa and the Williams, being quite the best we have seen there for a long time The first part of this turn is a clever knock-about acrobatic exhibition, and the second a laughable boxing burlesque. Mr. Brosa also introduces a couple of well-trained dogs. Another turn worthy of note is that of Les Sarraux, Spanish duettists and dancers, receiving well-(leserved applause. The rest of the programme includes The Sisters Litine, aerobatic dancers, who work very hard, Mlle Gaby, who has a good voice, and several artists of the French music hall type. Altogether to variety lovers the show is worth a visit.

div.head: Sngar Cultivation in Egypt.
div.p: It has been suggested that the prospects of sugar cultivation might be improved in two ways : first, by the promotion of experiments with a view to selecting the most productive varieties of cane ; secondly, by the extension of railway communication to the newly. converted basin lands in the Ibrahimieh region. As a result of the first suggestion, a number of experiments have been carried on by the Agri. cultural Society on the lands of individual cultivators. The crops are being harvested and promise satisfactory results. The Society has, at the same time, been in communication with other countries. With regard to the second inatter, the question of opening up railway commůnication with the western portion of the Ibrahimieh region is under consideration, but it is doubtful whether the new lines would offer any reasonable prospects of a fair return on the capital outlay unless rates were considerably raised. It might also very well be that the construction of these lines would operate in favour of the cultivation of crops other than sugar.

div.head: SIGNS OF FANATICISM.
div.p: A Damanhour correspondent states that the fellaheen in that neighbourhood declare that there will rising of Egyptian Moslemis on Shem el Nessim feast day.

A serious incident is reported from Minchat (Guirgueh province). A Copt had been converted to Islamism, and a procession was formed by a band of native streets youths, who ran through the streets hitting at and insulting the Christians, and it is said that this was done at the instigation of the moulahez of police. The inspector of the Ministry of the Interior and the sub-mondir are inquiring into the matter.

div.head: CLAYTON GAS CO. OF EGYPT.
div.p: The Clayton Gas Company of Egypt and the Sudan Limited, which was started a few weeks ago, has opened offices in Maison Mesciaca, Sharia Kasr-el Nil, Cairo. Offices are to be opened shortly at Alexandria, and agencies at Suez, Port Said and Port Sudan Mr. F. Mackinnon, M. I. M. E., has been appointed managing director Four steamboats are being built for the company's work at. Alexandria, Suez, Port Said, and Port Sudan. They are now being constructed by Messrs. Rennie and Company of Greenwich and are expected to arrive here before the summer is over. Portable plants for the disinfection of hospitals, barracks, railway carriages, hotels, etc. will be put down all over the country.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S RESIGNATION.
THE PROPOSED MEMORIAL.
NATIVE MUNICIPAL ATTITUDE.
div.p: The unanimous manner in which the native members of the Alexandria Municipality abstained from attending Sunday's meeting is the subject of universal comment. The Alexandria Municipality is the most important representative institution that exists in Egypt, and consequently the boycotting by the natives of the movement to present a memorial to Lord Cromer is of some significance. At the same time it must be remembered that none of the natives in the Municipal Commission have any claim to be considered as representative men, for only a single one of them has been elected. They have been nominated by the Government because, ac. cording to the constitution of the Municipality a certain number of persons have to be nominated, and the present Egyptian nominees were selected because they were supposed to be less prejudiced representatives of their race, owing to their contact with Europeans. They may be considered to be more or less representative of the native capitalist class in Alexandria, and for this reason their attitude deserves to be taken into consideration. As an excuse, it has been adduced that they think that, inas much as Lord Cromer is going, while the potent influences az nat him and all that he has represented still remain, therefore they are wise in maintaining an attitude which will be sure to be favourably considered in high places. From their own point of view they no doubt must be considered to be guided by prudential motives. The question of whether or not Yebia Pasha will serve on the committee chosen at Smmday's meeting of the Alexandria Municipality is much discussed. The fact that each member of this committee was selected to represent a nationality lends additional importance to the choice of Yehia Pasha to represent the Egyptians. Yehia Pasha is nominated by the Egyptian Government to his seat on the Alexandria Municipal Commission, as, in fact, are all the other native members, with the sole exception of Soliman Bey Abani, who is elected by the suffrages of the landlords. Consequently Yehia cannot well refuse to act, as if he did şo it would be taramount to a repudiation of the authority by which he holds his seat. As we said yesterday the best excuse thie Pasha can make is that he was so unwell that he could not attend the meeting on Sunday and that he is quite willing to serve on the Committee.

On the other hand his Excellency may have the courage of Nationalist opinions and as a devoted follower of Mustapha Pasha Kamel he may boldly refuse to serve on the committee in the name of "The Egyptian Nation." If he takes the determined course he will at once be raised to the foremost rank among Egyptian patriots and will be praised effusively in the columns of the "Egyptian Standard." Yehia Pasha, in fact, has to make his choice once and for all. If he decide to serve on the Committee he will be exposed to the objurgations of the vernacular Moslem Press as a time-server, while if he refuses to cast in his lot with all the European members of the commission, he will be hailed as one of those noble creatures who have refused to truckle to the brutal oppression of his country
PRESS COMMENTS.
The attitude of the native members of the Municipality is, as was to be expected, eulogissed by Mustapha Pasha Kamel The French cilition of "Al Lewa" says : --

The dignity and propriety of their attitude has been keenly appreciated in Alexandria, and it will be much talked about throughout Egypt. Lord Cromer has, during nearly twentyfive years, governed Egypt as absolute master, for the English, against e Egyptians. Let the English be grateful to him for it ; it is their duty ; let the Egyptians have no feeling of sympathy : that is their duty. In his last report - his farewell to Egypt-he has again laid stress npon his policy and his antipathy for the Egyptians. Not content with refusing them all that they with justice ask, he attacks, after having scoffed at their patriotism, their religion, Islam, which he has accused of being the obstacle to the civilisation and progress of the country over which he reigns. The Egyptians ove him no mask of affection, 10 homage of 'sympathy. But they owe him the silent deference due to the conquered ; for it is as a conquered màn that Lord Cromer goes away. The failure of his policy is the true reason of his departure. What then must the Egyptian members of the Alexandria Municipality do ? Abstain ; that was at the same time the most dignified and the most patriotic treatment Haid they attended the meeting they would only have been able to protest against the eulogies paid to the political enemy of Egypt and Islam. The lesson of silence (they understood it, and the whole world will hear of it with pleasure) was the noblest and the strongest.

"Les Nouvelles", commenting upon the absence of the native members, says :- It was in every reqpect an inopportune manifestation. The abstention of the native counsellors was undoubtedly legitimate. But in presence of the work which I ord Cromer leaves, one cannot, under penalty of ingratitude, obstinately declare it as bad, as those native counsellors appear to have done who did not go to express the thanks, which the Khedive himself believed it his duty to do, to the representative of the British Government.

"La Réforme" says :-- It was their right, assuredly, and we would be tempted to commend them for their attitude precisely because we estimate frankness above all. Yet these coun sellors might have attended the meeting and they might equally have taken part in the vote without being false to the ideas of which they are the two often discreet partisans,

div.head:
MEMORIAL TO LORD CROMER.
MEETING IN CAIRO.
div.p: A movement is on foot in Cairo, and may be said to have assumed concrete form, for Worthily commemorating the great services rendered to the European community by Lord Cromer during his long term of office

A meeting was held at the Savoy Hotel yesterday afternoon at half past five, to which the following prominent members of the Cairo European community, as representing the various nationalities, and forming the committee for the time bęing at all, events, were invited, and all were present with the exception of Maitre Carton de Wiart and Boghos Pasha Nubar :

Messrs. Beyerlé, Bretschneider, T. Caneri, Carton L. de Wiart, M. Cattaui Bey, Ad. Cattaui, Davidson, Dessales d'Epinoix, E. A. Harrison, Kerr, , MacLoughlin, Manugardi, Roghos Pasha Nubar, Pelizaeus, Rostovitz Bey, Rowlatt, Comte de Serionne, Messrs. Scott Dalgleish, R. Suares.

The Comte de Serionne was unanimously elected to take the chair, and, after expressing his appreciation of the honour, referred in eloquent terms to the great loss Egypt had sugtained by the resignation of Lord Cromer. He took it that the present meeting was mainly to nominate an actual committee with sub-committee in order to arrive at a decision as to in what form the European community could best perpetuate their recognition of the great and lasting work carried out in Egypt by Lord Cromer.

A general and somewhat desultory disorssion ensued, and the question was raised as to whether the proposed memorial or monument ! was to be international in the strict sense of the word, i.e. whether members of the native community should be asked to associate themselves with the European communities in the movement. It was pointed out that a committee, having in view the same purpose as that now sitting, had already been formed in Alexandria, and a member suggested that the two committees should exchange views, and possibly co-operate with one another. Nothing was known as to the constitation of the Alexandria committee, whether such committee was distinct from that of the Municipality, and whether the committee was actually international in character or composed solely of members of the European communities.
After lengthy discussion it was decided to elect a sub-committee, composed of the Comte de Serionne, (president) Messrs. Maurice Cattaui Bey, Manusardi, Pelizaeus, Rowlatt, and Rostovitz Buy.
This sub-committee are to exchange views with Alexandria, and draw up propositions to be submitted to the general committee.

The question as to the form of the memorial was discussed at length. It was, however, left over for consideration by the sub-committee, and Mr. Harrison's suggestion that Lord Cromer himself should be consulted on the question met with unanimous support.
The sub-committee meet again at the Savoy ! Hotel on Wednesday morning next at eleven.
M. Manse was elected secretary, with power to employ a paid clerk to assist him in the work.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI LTD.
div.p: It is to be hoped that the shareholders in Egypt of Walker and Meimarachi Limited, will take special pains to be represented at the forthcoming extraordinary general meeting of the company, which is to be held at the London offices of the company on next Monday! week, the 29th inst. The object for which the meeting is convened is to consider the question of the modification of the statutes of the company with a view to transferring the entire management from London to Cairo. To-day is the last day on which the local shareholders who want to be represented at this meeting, should place their shares with the Anglo.. Egyptian Bank at Cairo and Alexandria. | The necessity for this radical change in the constitution of the company has long been obvious as it is evident that in such an essentially local business, which caters solely for residents in this country, it is highly necessary to have a local board of directors, whose actions are neither controlled nor impeded from London. The London board of Walker and Meimarachi Limited has not been a signal success and has considerably hampered the freedom of action of the local board. The busi-! | mess capacities of the managing director in Egypt, Mr. Constantine Meimarachi, are well known and appreciated by all the clients of his company and the local shareholders. His energy and integrity command the confidence and esteem, without which such a business! cannot be successfully conducted, and if the sole guidance of the company is placed in the hands of Mr. Meimarachi and a local board of directors, there is no doubt that the future
prospects of the company will be far more al brilliant than if it is allowed to continue
| under its present conditions. There are plenty S of local precedents for the suppression of the
London boards of companies, whose sphere of operations is in Egypt and good results have
heen followed by handing over the undivided s'control to the men on the spot. These considIerations should carry weight with the
shareholders in Egypt and they should exert f themselves to be represented at the forthcoming
meeting.

div.head:
FINANCIAL CRISIS,
A POSSIBLE REMEDY.
MEASURES AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Many and various rumours were floating about yesterday as to certain definite measures, which had been decided on with a view to alleviating the existing crisis.

All these rumours are untrue and the only steps that have as yet been taken are the exchange of views. These are stilla proceeding between the leading persons in lo the local financial worl:l in order to relieve the situation. If mutual goodwill and cooperation be forthcoming, the situation may be materially improved. . '

Last night an extraordinary meeting was convened of the members of the Association des Courtiers en Valeurs' of the Alexandria Bourse in order to take decisive measures to prevent the continuous and factitious fall in local shares. It was decided to prohibit access to the corbeille" of all "remisiers" and "tenours de carnets." No exception is to be granted at all. Only authorised stock and sharebrokers or the "fondés de pouvoirs" of the agencies will be permitted henceforth in the corbeille. These measures came into force this lo morning and the results have been favourable for & noticeable firmness has taken place.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN POSTAL ADMINISTRATION.
SABA PASHA'S RETIREMENT.
div.p: The only reason which has induced Saba Pasha to seek to retire from the service of the f Egyptian Government is because he feels that I the time has come for him to seek a wellmerited repose after thirty-five years' service The Pasha is fifty-five years of age and under the Pension Law of 1887 he is entitled to retire on pension. The news will be received with a great deal of regret throughout Egypt and also in England where the Pasha's services on behalf of the Egyptian Post Office are well-known and deservedly appre. ciated. The staff of the Egyptian Postal Administration will hear that they are about to lose their chief, who has been PostmasterGeneral for twenty years, with sincere sorrow, for his Excellency is deservedly popular throughout all branches of the Administration over whose destinies he has so long and so ably presided.

The Pasha entered the Post Office on April 1st, 1872, and was appointed Postmaster General fifteen years later on the 1st January, 1887, The Pasha wrote to the Finance Minister yesterday asking to be permitted to retire, but up to now he has not received a reply.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT. MR. ROBERTSON'S QUESTIONS.
div.p: Mr. Robertson keeps on his policy of pestering Sir Edward Greey with ques. tions every Thursday. The following were asked on the 11th inst. and telegraphed to "Al Lewa" :| Mr. J. M, Robertson : What is the amount of secret service money annually granted to Lord Cromer and Sir Reginald Wingate!
Sir Edward Grey : It could not be stated, | as otherwise the fund would no longer be secret.
Mr. J. M. Robertson : Who appointed the Board of Concessions for the sale of Govern'ment Land; how did it happen there were no i Egyptiaris on it : and what were the conces. sions granted ?
Sir Edward Grey :- There was no information to be given on the subject as it did not fall within the competence of the Foreign
Secretary | Mr. J. M. Robertson :- Asks for informar

tion referring to the punishing of landholder, by the withdrawal of the water supply from their lands. 1 Sir Edward Grey :-There was no information to be given on the subject as the Foreign Secretary could not interfere in the matter, being sure of the good work of the men
in Egypt. 1 Mr. J.M. Robertson :- What subsidies are
granted to "Al-Mokattam," "Al-Watan" and "Le Progrès."
Sir Edward Grey :-There was no informaition to be given on the matter, and even if there were, the Foreign Secretary would decline to give it.

div.head: FIRE AT KAFR SANBIDI.
div.p: Shibin el Kom Tuesday. A serious village fire occured at Kafr Sanbidi in the Shibin el Kom Markaz yesterday afternoon, resulting in the death of 8 persons. Most of the houses in the village were destroyed as well as a large number of cattle.

div.head: MATARIEH BURNT DOWN.
div.p: A telegram has been received from Mansourah stating that a serious outbreak of fire occurred at Matarieh at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon and raged on into the night; the town of Matarieh is completely destroyed, including the station. The origin of the outbreak is unknown.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Khephren sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon for Tripoli (Barbary) and is due here on Sunday next, with passengers, ad and general cargo.
The Moss liner Menes sailed from Liverpool and last Sunday and in due here about 28th inst. with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

div.head:
AN EGYPTIAN LOURDES.
THE MARBLE CITY OF MARIOUT.
div.p: It is almost incredible that the ruins of a celebrated city, the holiest site in Christian Egypt, could have remained unknown for nine hundred years in the immediate neighbourhood of such a populous centre as Alexandria. Although it was well known that the site of the City of Saint Menas, the Patron Saint of Christian Egypt, did exist in the Mariout district, it was not until less than two years age that the wonderful remains of the holy city were brought to light by the researches of two German archieologists. The city lies a few hours ride to the north of Beheig on the Khedive's railway in a breezy upland tract, 29 metres above sea level. The surrounding district is uninhabited save by a few Bedouin and lies away from any desert highway except that followed by the hashish smugglers, who lead their camels on dark nights near the old city on their way to Delingat, where hashish can more safely be disposed of than at Mex or Alexandria. The country round is a bleak expanse of steppe, cultivated here and there with barley, the green surface often varied by low mounds, relics of ancient habitations. Far away in the south runs a line of rising country, the haunt of the gazelle. Here the desert plateau begins and continues unbroken until the Wady Natron is reached. But in ancient times when Nitria, was one of the greatest centres of Monasticism in Christendom, the home of thirty thousand monks, and the City of Saint Menas, the most revered shrine in Egypt, there must have been a considerable traffic from Alexandria by this ronte for the city lay on the direct track to the Natron Valley and its fifty monasteries, from which it is a ten hours ride on horseback.
*THE ANCIENT CITY.

Even in its present state of desolation it is easy to see the magnificence of the ancient city. The profusion of marble is extraordinary and the choicest samples lie about everywhere amidst the ruins. The churches, monasteries and basilicas were all of marble and the great marble basilica of the Emperor Arcadius must have been visible for miles and miles throughout Mariout. No doubt this profusion of to marble came from the Serapeum, for in the to reign of Theodosius, the father of Arcadius, the extirpation of paganism took place, of which the destruction of the great temple of Alexandria was one of the results.

The town was exclusively a city of pilgrim-lo age, an Egyptian Lourdes, and hither came crowds from all parts of Christendom. The world-wide sanctity of the spot is evident by the fact that there is not a museum in Europe which has not one or more specimens of the terra-cotta flasks (ampullie) of the holy water; of Saint Menas, which the pilgrims brought back with them to their homes in Europe. There is a fine collection of one hundred and sixty of these ampullæ at the Alexandria Museums and good samples are to be found in the British Museum, the National Library at Paris, the Museums at Florence and Berlin and elsewhere. There is also in the British Museum an exquisite ivory vase with scenes from the life of Saint Menas engraved upon its sides.
SAINT MENAS,
church ho gave forthas soon as h

The Patron Saint of Christian Egypt was a soldier, who was martyred in Phrygia in one! of the Diocletian persecutions (296 A D.). The 1 body was brought to Alexandria and placed upon a camel, which was let loose to follow what course it chese In the place the camel stopped, near Lake Mareotis, & grave was made and a shrine subsequently built. Menas belonged to a good family, his father being the Governor of an African Province, and he was an officer in the army when he refused to renounce Christianity. His martyrdom therefore made some stir and as soon as he was buried his tomb gave forth miraculous - powers. A 1 church was built there and soon a town sprang up owing to the lacrative pilgrimage traffic The fame of the Saint went on increasing and a great basilica was erected in the reign of Arcadius (395-408 A.D.). Even after the Moslem conquest Orthodox and Jacobite Copts struggled to possess the sanctuary. Sabsequent to the terrible outbreak of Moslem fanaticism under the Caliph El-Hakim (9951021 A.D.) when the great destruction of Christian Churches took place all traces of the ancient city disappeared, for the last extant account of it is from an unknown Arab traveller who visited it probably in the tenth century. The description is contained in a manuscript in the Paris Library and is as follows :- " Leaving Tarraneh and following the road towards Barca, one comes to Mena, whch consists of three abandoned towns, in the midst of a sandy desert, with their buildings still standing. The Arabs use it as a place for lying in wait for travellers. There may be seen lofty and well built palaces with enclosure walls around them. They are for the most part built over vaulted colonnades and some few serve as dwellings for monks. There are some springs of fresh water but they are somewhat scanty Next one comes to the Church of Saint Menas, a huge building decorated with statues and paintings of the greatest beauty. There tapers burn day and night without ceasing. At one end of the church is a vast tomb with two camels in marble, and upon them the statue of a man' carved in marble, who is standing with one
foot upon each camel. One of his hands is open i and the other closed. This statue is said to
represent Saint Menas. On the right as you
*An excellent series of photographs of the excava. tions have been taken by Messrs. Reiser and Binder, Alexandria.

enter the church is a great marble column, in which a shrine is carved containing figures of Jesus, John and Zacharias...... There is also to be seen a statue of the Virgin Mary, hidden by two curtains, and statues of all the prophets. Outside the church are figures representing all kinds of animals and men of all ocoupations. Among others is a slave merchant holding in his hand a purse upside down. Over the midst of the church is & dome beneath which are eight figures said to represent angels. Close to the church is a mosque, where the Moslems come to pray..All the surrounding land. is planted with fruit trees. The fruit is very good and used for making syrup. There are also a great many vines from which which wine is made."

This description proves that for long after the Arab conquest, although the city was uninhabited, yet it was still intact, bat the anknown Arab traveller wrote these lines in the tanth century before the opnquest of England by the Normans and from that time until June, 1905, the marble city of the Patron Saint of Egypt remained lost amidst the wilds. of Mariout. The vines and fruit trees have all gone, the springs are dried up and not a single visitor save the wandering Bedouin have ever passed by the ruined basilicas and monasteries of the Lourdes of Christian Egypt. Although the feast of Saint Menas has always been kept up by the Orthodox, Jacobite and Abyssinian Churches and the flasks of the holy oil of the Saint have been collected in all the museums of Europe the mystery surrounding the site of the city appeared to be as insoluble as that of the equally recondite Wady el-Malook in Upper Egypt, until the learned world of Enrope was lately apprised of the fact that the city had at last been found by two German savants.
The story of this discovery and an account of the excavations will appear in another issue.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Edward Cecil, Under-Secretary of State at the Finance Ministry, will be replaced during his absence by Chitty Bey on the Special Council of Discipline.

A telegram from our Shibin el Kom Correg. pondent announces that Saad Pasha Zagloul, Minister of Education, has postponed his visit to that village until next Monday, as he had to attend the ceremony of the reception of the Mahmal in Cairo yesterday.

Mrs. Chataway's garden party at Nouzha Gardens yesterday afternoon was, as usual, one of the most fashionable social events of the Alexandria season. The charming hostess with her usual hospitality had made elaborate

prepártions for the delight of her hundreds of I guests. Numbers of tables for refreshments and tea were arranged over the lawns of these lovely gardens, and the band played a selection of airs during the proceedings. Mrs. Chata way's numerous guests remained until a late hour, and every body left delighted with the pleasant afternoon they had spent.

1 The Hon. Arthur Davey, lately one of the directors at Cairo of the "Sucreries Company," has been bequested £5000 by his. father, the late Lord Davey, who left estate valued at £172,398 gross, with net personalty £165,767
Miralai Stanton Boy and Mrs Stanton left Khartoum last week on their way to England. Kaimakam Young Boy, Sub-Governor of Khartoum Province will act for the Gov. ernor during the latter's absence,

Three months' leave of absence has been granted to Major E. Paterson, D.3.0., Inniskilling Dragoons, Captain R.G.B. Jeffreys, 1st Bn. Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Liegt. T.H.C. Frankland, 1st Bn, Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Lieut. F.B. Nixon, Inniskilling Dragoons, all dating from the first week of June.

At the next meeting of the Council of Ministera a decree will be sanctioned appointing M. Laloi, President of the Algiers Court, to the Cairo Mixed Tribunals, in place of M. Bourgueil, who has declined the post.
Mr. Archibald, sub-director and professor of Civil Law at the Khedivial Law School has resigned. "Al Moayad" states that Omar Bey Loutfy will succeed him.

The marriage of Dr. E. Maynard Pain, of the Church Missionary Society's Hospital, Old Cairo, to Miss Mildred Brougham Docker, second daughter of Judge Docker, of Sydney, Australia, will take place at All Saints' Church, Cairo, next Monday at 9.30 a.m.
A marriage has been arranged between M. Joseph Mondolfo' and Miss Jeanne Adda, | daughter of Maitre Cesar Adda.

Mr. and Mrs. Timins have taken over the lease of Mr. Shreiber's house, situated behind Capt Blakeney's on the new road at Zeitoun, end will reside with their children there from April 15th until they leave for Europe about August 1st.. 1 Mr. Ernest Walton, who was for three years business manager of the Sphinx" newspaper e at Cairo, is leaving Egypt to day and will take up his new duties in London as advertisement n manager of the "African World."
Ti M. Galvin, sub-manager of the Cairo Water Company, is retiring after twenty years' service.
Nouri Bey, secretary to Chazi Mukhtar 1. Pasha, will shortly return to Cairo from Constantinople.

div.p: AVIS
Le public est informé que la vente au enchères des 130 poutrelles en fer se trouvant a la Rue Chounet el Tainat, fixée au lundi 15 courant, a été annulée.
Alexandrie, le 10 Avril 1907.
L'Administrateur :
30018-3-3 Sig. W. P. CHATAWAY.
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de démolition des Immeubles et mure, recouvrant les lots du Jardin Français et BO trouvant Place Mohamed Aly. Le cautionnement est fixé L.6g. 50.

Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adres ées sons pli oacbeté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 23 Avril 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées en téftnoe de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.

L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission poor démolition Immeuble et murs, des lots du Jardin Fia; çais." Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les condirions du cabier des charges, devra être remis séparément an Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouvertare des offres et aa plus tard le 23 Avril à midi. Tonte offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessas sera écartée.
L'Administratear (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 12 Avril 1907. 30031 S 1
AVIS
La Mnnioipalité met en adjudication l'é quanissage des animaBx morts dans le périmètre de la ville d'Alexandrie.
Le cautionnement est fixé h LE. 60 (Soix ante).
Le oahier des charges est dépo-é au bure -u Banitaire où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les joare de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 31 Décembre 1907.
Elles pourront également être déposées eu séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : " Soumission pour l'Equarrisaga des Animanx.

Le cautionnement on le reçu d'nne banque, d'après le* conditions du cahior des charges, devra être remis séparément an Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'onvertnre des offres et an pins tard le 31 Déoembie 1907 à midi.
Tonte offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions oi dessus sera écartée
L'Administrateur
(Signé) W.-P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 13 Avril 1907. 30032-3-1

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
